Hi everybody,

I was away from work since I posted this message.
Thank you all for your inputs. I will go through all
of the responses and revert.

Thanks once again for the overwhelming support.
Srikanth
 
--- Chris Dollin <chris.dollin@...> wrote:
> On Monday 05 April 2004 17:55, Jason Rogers wrote:
> > While that is true, it is irrelevant to his
> example test (unless I
> > missed something about my "simple" explanation and
> your correction)
> > because he wasn't reassigning the original
> variable.  But alas, I
> > believe we are off-topic now.  You are correct in
> the sense that it
> > reduces memory usage, but as a habit (personally)
> I feel it should be
> > avoided.  If I must optimize, this is surely a
> good optimization place.
> > For example:
> >
> >   BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new
> FileReader(file));
> >   String line = null;
> >   while ( (line = reader.readLine()) != null ) {
> >     doSomethingWith(line);
> >   }
> >
> > is _MUCH_ cheaper (in terms of allocation) than:
> >
> >   BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new
> FileReader(file));
> >   while ( reader.ready() ) {
> >     String line = reader.readLine();
> >     doSomethingWith(line);
> >   }
> 
> I don't see why you think this: in both cases all
> the interesting allocation
> happens inside readLine. Where the local variable is
> declared is going
> to make essentially no difference. [Internally,
> "line" is a reference value
> of fixed size, allocated in the method's
> stack-frame; it's not an object
> allocated in the heap [1], so going round the loop
> redeclaring it doesn't
> burn store. It would be different if we were in a
> language with full lexical
> scoping like Scheme or Pop11, and the variable was
> captured by a closure,
> but we aren't and we cant.]
> 
> [1] I can imagine an implementation that allocated
> stack-frames on the
> heap, as NJSML does, but even that doesn't allocate
> individual variables
> on the heap in cases like this.
> 
> -- 
> Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
